Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to leave for my Saturday morning volunteer shift. It was a message from Mom: “Can we talk for a bit? Haven’t heard from you all week.” I glanced at the clock—if I didn’t leave now, I’d be late opening the community center, and people would be left waiting outside in the cold. I was the only volunteer scheduled this morning, and the coordinator had stressed how important it was to be on time. But Mom’s message tugged at me. She and Dad always worried when I went quiet, and I knew they expected me to check in, especially on weekends. I could picture her waiting by the phone, hoping for a call. My keys jingled in my hand as I hesitated in the hallway, torn between the warmth of my family’s concern and the responsibility I felt toward the people counting on me at the center. My heart pounded as I stood there, caught between two worlds, unsure which door to walk through first.
